The rlmN gene encodes a dual-specificity methyltransferase that modifies 23S rRNA at adenine 2503 (A2503) and tRNA at adenine 37 (A37). In Escherichia coli, RlmN catalyzes the formation of 2-methyladenosine (m²A) at position 2503 in 23S rRNA and at position 37 in a subset of tRNAs[1][2][5]. This modification in rRNA is associated with antibiotic resistance (specifically to phenicol, lincosamide, oxazolidinone, pleuromutilin, and streptogramin A antibiotics, collectively known as PhLOPSa) in some bacteria[1]. <gene_function>
The *rlmN* gene encodes a dual-specificity methyltransferase that catalyzes the formation of 2-methyladenosine (m²A) at position 2503 in 23S rRNA and position 37 in tRNA[1][2]. This enzyme is iron-sulfur cluster-dependent and conserved across diverse bacteria, including gram-negative models like *Escherichia coli*[1][2][5]. In *E. coli*, RlmN methylates A2503 in the ribosomal peptidyl transferase center and A37 in tRNA, impacting both translation fidelity and antibiotic resistance[1][2]. While no direct studies in *Prochlorococcus* were found, phylogenetic analyses indicate *rlmN* homologs are widespread in bacteria[1], suggesting a conserved role in marine cyanobacteria.

</gene_function>

<physiological_impact>
RlmN-mediated methylation directly influences cellular physiology by modulating ribosomal and tRNA function. Methylation at 23S rRNA A2503 alters ribosome structure, affecting protein synthesis efficiency[1][5]. In tRNA, m²A37 modification prevents translational frameshifting and enhances codon-anticodon stability[2]. These modifications collectively optimize translation under varying environmental conditions, though *Prochlorococcus*-specific physiological impacts remain unstudied.

</physiological_impact>

This suggests potential involvement in stress adaptation, though no direct links to nutrient limitation or oxidative stress in marine microbes were found. The enzyme’s iron-sulfur cluster may render it sensitive to redox changes[2], but experimental evidence in cyanobacteria is lacking.
